javadoc:
The primary interface for graphs that are to be rendered. This class defines methods commonly used in the GUI while extending the primary non-visual graph interface.

The Visual Graph API will typically provide services for taking a Visual Graph and creating a UI that handles basic user interaction elements (similar to how complex Java widgets handle user interaction for the developer). The Visual Graph is the model of the UI components. A typical Visual Graph UI will render developer-defined components, handling mouse event translations for the developer.

Some features found in Visual Graphs:

  • Mouse event translation - the JComponent being rendered in the graph will be handed mouse events that are relative to its coordinate space, not that of the graph.
  • Hover and Selection - vertex hover and selection events are handled by the API
  • Zooming - zoom level and related events (when zoomed too far, mouse events are not passed-through to the component) and handled by the API
@param the vertex type @param the edge type

methods.name: vertexLocationChanged
methods.comment: A callback notifying this graph that the given vertex's location has changed

methods.javadoc:
Returns the focused vertex; null if no vertex has focus.  Focus is equivalent to 
 being selected, but further distinguishes the vertex as being the only selected 
 vertex.  This is useful for key event processing.
@return the focused vertex
methods.name: getFocusedVertex
methods.comment:
Returns the focused vertex; null if no vertex has focus.  Focus is equivalent to 
 being selected, but further distinguishes the vertex as being the only selected 
 vertex.  This is useful for key event processing.

methods.javadoc:
Sets the given vertex to be focused or not

Note: this method is called by other APIs to ensure that the graph's notion of the focused vertex matches what is happening externally (e.g., from the user clicking the screen). If you wish to programmatically focus a vertex, then you should not be calling this API directly, but you should instead be using the {@link GPickedState} or one of the APIs that uses that, such as the {@link GraphComponent}. @param v the focused vertex @param b true for focused; false for not focused
methods.name: setVertexFocused
methods.comment:
Sets the given vertex to be focused or not
 
 Note: this method is called by other APIs to ensure that the graph's notion of the 
 focused vertex matches what is happening externally (e.g., from the user clicking the
 screen).  If you wish to programmatically focus a vertex, then you should not be calling
 this API directly, but you should instead be using the GPickedState or one
 of the APIs that uses that, such as the GraphComponent.

params.name: b
params.comment: true for focused; false for not focused

methods.javadoc: Clears any selected vertices as well as the focused vertex
methods.name: clearSelectedVertices
methods.comment: Clears any selected vertices as well as the focused vertex

methods.javadoc:
Selects the given vertices

Note: this method is called by other APIs to ensure that the graph's notion of the focused vertex matches what is happening externally (e.g., from the user clicking the screen). If you wish to programmatically select a vertex, then you should not be calling this API directly, but you should instead be using the {@link GPickedState} or one of the APIs that uses that, such as the {@link GraphComponent}. @param vertices the vertices
methods.name: setSelectedVertices
methods.comment:
Selects the given vertices
 
 Note: this method is called by other APIs to ensure that the graph's notion of the 
 focused vertex matches what is happening externally (e.g., from the user clicking the
 screen).  If you wish to programmatically select a vertex, then you should not be calling
 this API directly, but you should instead be using the GPickedState or one
 of the APIs that uses that, such as the GraphComponent.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the selected vertices.
@return the selected vertices
methods.name: getSelectedVertices

methods.javadoc:
Adds the given listener to this graph
@param l the listener
methods.name: addGraphChangeListener
methods.comment: Adds the given listener to this graph

methods.javadoc:
Removes the given listener from this graph
@param l the listener
methods.name: removeGraphChangeListener
methods.comment: Removes the given listener from this graph

methods.javadoc:
Returns the layout that has been applied to the graph.  The graph does not need its 
 layout to function, but rather it is convenient for the visual graph system to be able
 to get the layout from the graph, rather than passing the layout everywhere it is 
 needed.
@return the layout applied to the graph
methods.name: getLayout
methods.comment:
Returns the layout that has been applied to the graph.  The graph does not need its 
 layout to function, but rather it is convenient for the visual graph system to be able
 to get the layout from the graph, rather than passing the layout everywhere it is 
 needed.

return.comment: the layout applied to the graph

name: VisualGraph
comment:
The primary interface for graphs that are to be rendered.  This class defines methods 
 commonly used in the GUI while extending the primary non-visual graph interface.
 
 The Visual Graph API will typically provide services for taking a Visual Graph and 
 creating a UI that handles basic user interaction elements (similar to how complex Java
 widgets handle user interaction for the developer).  The Visual Graph is the model of the
 UI components.  A typical Visual Graph UI will render developer-defined components, 
 handling mouse event translations for the developer. 
  
 Some features found in Visual Graphs:
 
 	Mouse event translation - the JComponent being rendered in the graph will be handed 
      mouse events that are relative to its coordinate space, not that of the graph.
 	
  Hover and Selection - vertex hover and selection events are handled by the API
  
  Zooming - zoom level and related events (when zoomed too far, mouse events are 
      not passed-through to the component) and handled by the API
